# Map Projections
## From sphere to plane


```{r, out.width="60%", fig.align="center", fig.cap="Photo by Valentin Lacoste on Unsplash"}

masthead <- "assets/valentin-lacoste-unsplash.jpg"
knitr::include_graphics(masthead, dpi=72)

```

<div class="figure-text">Hole, Yunnan, China</div>

> You mean to tell me that China is under us? China is under us?\
It's not. The world is flat.\
--- Shaquille O'Neal\

***

In cartography, a map projection is a way to __flatten a globe's__ surface into a plane in order to make a map. This requires a systematic transformation of the latitudes and longitudes of locations from the surface of the globe into locations on a plane. All projections of a sphere on a plane necessarily __distort__ the surface in some way and to some extent. Depending on the purpose of the map, some distortions are acceptable and others are not; therefore, different map projections exist in order to __preserve__ some properties of the sphere-like body at the expense of other properties such as angle or size.

### Load Map
#### Natural Earth

```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, echo=TRUE, class.source='fold-show'}

ne_world <- ne_countries(scale = "small", returnclass = "sf")

```


### Coordinate Reference System
#### Set crs


A coordinate reference system (CRS) refers to the way in which spatial data that represent the earthâ€™s surface are flattened so that you can represent them on a 2-dimensional surface.

```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, echo=TRUE, class.source='fold-show'}

ne_world <- ne_world %>% st_as_sf() %>% st_set_crs(4326)

```


### Reprojected
#### Orthographic


```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, echo=TRUE, class.source = 'fold-hide', out.width = "100%"}

theme_opts <- theme(
  legend.position = "none",
  legend.title = element_blank(),
  axis.text = element_blank(),
  #axis.line = element_blank(),
  axis.ticks = element_blank(),
  axis.title = element_blank(),
  #panel.grid = element_blank(),
  #panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
  #panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
  panel.background = element_blank(),
  panel.border = element_blank(),
  plot.background = element_blank(),
)

v1 = ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = ne_world, color="#AAAAAA", fill="#FFFFFF", size=0.5) +
  scale_x_continuous() +
  scale_y_continuous() +
  coord_sf(crs = "+proj=ortho") +
  theme_bw() +
  labs(x="", # Longitude
       y="", # Latitude
       title = "Natural Earth", 
       subtitle="Orthographic") +
  theme_opts

girafe(ggobj = v1, width_svg = 16, height_svg = 9,
       options = list(opts_sizing(rescale = TRUE, width = 1.0))
)

```
